snippet: There are a few hundred therapists in Afghanistan, mainly treating women in a nation of people besieged by war, malnutrition, post-traumatic stress, depression and domestic violence.
abstract: Profile of Farkhunda Shahab, one of only five female therapists in the Afghan province of Kapisa; Shahab is at forefront of effort to improve mental health in war-torn region, caring for dozens of patients including abused women and children mourning the death of their parents; Shahab has persisted in her work despite challenges of personal poverty, malnourished children and an opium-addicted husband.

byline.contributor: Mariam Jalalzada contributed reporting from Kapisa Province, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: There are a few hundred therapists in Afghanistan, mainly treating women in a nation of people besieged by war, malnutrition, post-traumatic stress, depression and domestic violence.

headline.main: For a Therapist in Afghanistan, Empathy Is Good Medicine
headline.print_headline: Afghan Therapist Finds Empathy Is Good Medicine
